rounds.observation:
You are Player 0 in the Negotiation Game.
You have some resources, and your task is to trade such that the total value of your resources increases.
The resources and associated values you currently have are:
	+ [Wheat]   Qty: 21   Value: 5
	+ [Wood]    Qty: 19   Value: 11
	+ [Sheep]   Qty: 15   Value: 12

	+ [Ore]     Qty: 10   Value: 40
At each turn, you can talk to your opponent and make a trade offer.
Use the following special tokens for actions:

  - '[Accept]': To accept an incoming offer.
  - '[Deny]': To deny an incoming offer (default).
The game lasts for 10 turns in total.

	+ [Ore]     Qty: 16   Value: 40

  - '[Accept]': To accept an incoming offer.

The game lasts for 10 turns in total.
 Player 0 made the following offer to Player 1: Offered items: 5 Wheat, 5 Wood -> Requested items: 5 Brick, 3 Sheep
rounds.response:
Let me evaluate their proposal first.

Value I would receive (what I’m getting):
- 5 Wheat × 6 = 30
- 5 Wood × 8 = 40
Value = 70

Value I would give away (what I’m losing):
- 5 Brick × 27 = 135
- 3 Sheep × 14 = 42
Value = 177

Net change for me: 70 – 177 = –107.  
That’s a bad deal that significantly lowers my total value, so I should refuse.

[Deny]

rounds.response:
Let me quickly check the values in the last offer to be sure what their proposal was worth.

Offer they just sent:
- They give me: 5 Wheat (5×6 = 30) + 5 Wood (5×8 = 40) = 70 value
- I must give them: 5 Brick (5×27 = 135) + 3 Sheep (3×14 = 42) = 177 value  
Net loss for me: 70 – 177 = −107 → naturally I already rejected it.

Current (Turn 2) – I still have:
– Wheat 14 (6)
– Wood 24 (8)
– Sheep 10 (14)
– Brick 22 (27)
– Ore 16 (40)

My high-value stock is Ore (40 per) and Brick (27 per).  
I could spare some Ore to get more Brick, or offload some low-value Wood/Wheat.

Proposal to Player 0:
[Offer: 4 Ore, 5 Wheat -> 9 Brick]

rounds.response:
Let me do the numbers on the incoming offer so I don’t accept anything that drops my total value.

Opponent offer:
Player 0 → Player 1  
Gives: 5 Wheat + 5 Wood (→ +30 value in my store)  
Asks: 5 Brick + 3 Sheep (→ ‑165 value taken out of my store)  
Net Δ-value = 30 – 165 = −135.  
That’s a huge loss, so I must reject.

I don’t see any urgent need to propose a new deal right now—nothing looks obviously worth it and the board’s quiet. So:

[Deny]

rounds.response:
I want to squeeze more value out of the game, so let’s look at the current situation.

My current holdings and values  
- 14 Wheat (6 ea → 84 value)  
- 24 Wood  (8 ea → 192 value)  
- 10 Sheep (14 ea → 140 value)  
- 22 Brick (27 ea → 594 value)  ← I’m Brick-rich but value it highest among mine.  
- 16 Ore   (40 ea → 640 value)

Key insight  
- Ore is my single most valuable good (40).  
- Brick is also high-valued, but I hold 22—already plenty for any likely end-game needs.  
- Giving up a little Brick (27) for more Ore (40) nets a large swing in my favor.

Trade logic  
I need to make an offer Player 0 might accept while still improving my position.  
I’m willing to part with 5 of my 22 Brick (cost = 5 × 27 = 135 value in Brick) and receive 3 extra Ore (gain = 3 × 40 = 120 value in Ore) and 3 extra Wheat (gain = 3 × 6 = 18 value in Wheat).  
Net change for me: –135 + 120 + 18 = +3 value.  
Small but positive, and Brick is the only item Player 0 has been chasing all game, so the mix may appeal to them.

[Offer: 3 Ore, 3 Wheat -> 5 Brick]

rounds.response:
I’m at turn 10 right now with only seconds to act.  
My key observation: Brick (value 27) is the only resource I still lack, so any successful swap must bring in more Brick than I ship out. I also want to give up as little Ore (40) and Sheep (14 each) as possible, since they are my high-value pieces.

What I need:

- 9 Brick would give me net +243 value if I could buy it for 3 Ore (3×40=120 value shipped).  
- Even at 4 Ore for 9 Brick (160 vs 243) I’m still up good.

So here’s my final, best shot—lower Ore and higher total value for me:

[Offer: 3 Ore, 5 Wheat -> 9 Brick]
